content: How can I help you today?
I've been having trouble sleeping lately, and my partner suggested I should talk to someone about it. I’m feeling really skeptical about all this, though.

Trouble sleeping can be tough and frustrating, especially when it starts to affect other parts of life. It's understandable to feel skeptical about opening up or making changes. What has been going through your mind about it so far?
Lately, I’ve just been really stressed about work. I keep worrying I might get fired, and it’s all I think about when I try to sleep. It’s like my brain won’t shut off.

That sounds overwhelming—feeling stressed about work and carrying that worry into the night can make it hard to get the rest you need. It's impressive that you're aware of how these thoughts are impacting your sleep. What's been working for you, if anything, to try and quiet your mind?

I’ve been using my phone to try and distract myself, scrolling through social media or watching videos. But I think it just makes things worse because it adds more to my head. I just feel stuck in this loop.

It seems like you're trying to find ways to escape the stress, but using your phone might be adding to the mental load rather than easing it. Feeling stuck in a loop can be tough—it’s like you’re trying to reset but the cycle keeps pulling you back. What keeps you from trying something else to unwind?
Honestly, I don't even know what else to try. Everything feels kind of pointless when my mind is racing like this. Plus, I feel like I can't focus long enough to even try something new.

It sounds like the worrying and the racing thoughts are really draining your energy and making it hard to even think about alternatives. That’s tough—feeling trapped in that cycle can make everything seem harder. What about this situation would you most like to change, if it were possible?

I guess I’d really like to just feel calm when I go to bed, like I’m not carrying all this stress with me. If I could just turn off my thoughts and actually fall asleep, I think it would help me handle everything better.

Wanting to feel calm at night and leave the stress behind makes a lot of sense—it sounds like you're craving that sense of peace to help you recharge and take on the challenges of your day. Feeling calm and rested could really make a difference. What would it mean for you to get closer to that goal?

I think it would mean I could be more present with my family and actually focus on work without feeling so drained all the time. I’d probably feel more like myself again, and maybe less worried about letting everyone down if I lose my job.

Finding that calm could help you re-connect with yourself and your loved ones and feel more focused at work, which sounds really important to you. Imagine how it would feel to have that energy and presence again—what do you think might help you move toward that, even in small steps?

I'm not sure. I just feel like my mind's in overdrive all the time, and it’s hard to think about what could even work. Maybe I need to figure out how to deal with these thoughts first before anything else?

That’s a thoughtful insight—addressing the constant racing thoughts might be key to unlocking other changes. It sounds like you’re open to exploring what could calm your mind, which is a great starting point. Is there anything you’ve ever tried in the past, even outside of this situation, that helped you manage stress or overwhelming thoughts?

Hmm, I don't think I've ever really found anything that works. I've always just powered through things or distracted myself, like with my phone. Maybe that's why I'm feeling so stuck now—I don't really have strategies for coping with all this stress.

It sounds like you've relied on sheer willpower and distractions to get through tough times, but now, facing this level of stress, those approaches don’t seem to be enough anymore. That shows a lot of self-awareness, recognizing that something deeper might need to shift. What do you think you’d need for coping that feels more helpful or effective at this point?
Maybe something that helps me slow my mind down or gets me out of my head a bit. I just don’t really know where to start or if it’d even make a difference right now.

It sounds like you’re looking for something to help you feel more in control, to slow things down and ease the weight of the thoughts you're carrying. Feeling unsure about starting is natural, especially when it feels overwhelming. If you decided to give something new a try, what kind of approach might feel doable for you? Something simple or gradual, perhaps?

I think keeping it simple sounds like a good idea because I don’t want to feel overwhelmed trying something new. Maybe just finding one small thing to start with, like taking a few minutes before bed to breathe or sit quietly. I’m not sure if that’ll work, but it feels less daunting than trying to overhaul everything at once.

Starting with something small, like taking a few quiet minutes to breathe or sit, sounds like a gentle and achievable step. It’s a way to take back a little control without pushing yourself too hard. You’re showing a lot of thoughtfulness about what feels realistic right now. Is there anything else you'd want to talk about or explore before thinking about moving forward?
